body: A typical teen-age squabble was on the verge of erupting into something nastier in the cafeteria at Junior High School in the Bronx: one girl accused another of glaring and threatened "to get my friends and jump you after school." But this time, an alert teacher stepped in and persuaded the pair to go to the school's Mediation Center, where they
title: Reacting to Rising Violence, Schools Introduce 'Fourth R': Reconciliation

body: "Haven't you ever wanted to put your foot through your television screen?" asked an actor in "Media Burn," an outdoor spectacle staged in 1975 by the performance art collective Ant Farm. The answer, 15 years later, is a resounding "Yes!" Now, a generation of artists who grew up with television are beginning to rebel against it. Following Ant Farm's
title: The Merry Pranksters And the Art of the Hoax

body: Over the last three months, a woman who supervised a school bus carrying handicapped children in Brooklyn sexually abused seven of the students repeatedly, the police charged yesterday. The police said the woman abused the children in the back of the bus while they were on the way home from Public School 38, at 450 Pacific Street in the Boerum Hill
title: Bus Matron Charged in Sex Abuse of Handicapped Students

body: LEAD: Four-year-old Hannah Goodwin happily bobbed up and down on her pale gray horse, but 3-year-old Jonathan Hausch preferred the bright orange lion with the bushy mane to his colorful wooden steed. body: LEAD: During the giddy 1980's, restaurants from Columbus Avenue to TriBeCa reverberated with customer boasts of shrewd real-estate deals and tales of manic co-op profits. title: Realty Slump Traps Some as Buyers Nibble Warily

body: LEAD: David and Toni small have just spent $50,000 to improve their home in Lake Hopatcong, N.J. The updated kitchen has new oak cabinets, a new floor of Mexican tiles, new pale yellow countertops and new appliances. title: Residential Remodeling Making Gains

body: LEAD: Rare is the New Yorker who has strolled past a row of stately town houses and not fantasized about living in one. But even rarer is the apartment-dweller not made uneasy by stories of leaking roofs, burglaries, broken boilers and the large sums of money such houses consume. The drawback is isolation. title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters; Some Caveats on Buying a Town House

body: LEAD: In the pulpits of churches in black neighborhoods yesterday, some ministers urged compassion for three black teen-agers convicted in the Central Park jogger case. body: LEAD: The closest Leonardo Laziza has come to a real gun was when he saw one, at eye level, on a police officer's hip, tucked inside a holster. But Leonardo, a 6-year-old from Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, said he could identify two kinds of firearms, ''a pistol and a bazooka,'' both from movies and cartoons. title: Shootings Jolt Children to New Views of Guns

body: LEAD: Since emigrating from his native Guyana 21 years ago, John Grant has built a thriving residential renovation business in Brooklyn while buying up empty lots in his Boerum Hill neighborhood and dreaming of the day when he could build homes from scratch. body: LEAD: Joseph Fama, a 19-year-old white man from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, was convicted last night of the racial killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins, the 16-year-old black youth who went to the mostly white neighborhood to help a teen-age friend shop for a used car. Joseph Fama, a 19-year-old white man from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn,
title: The Bensonhurst Case; Bensonhurst Defendant Is Found Guilty

body: LEAD: Nine of the jurors who convicted Joseph Fama of murder declared last night that they were convinced he was part of the white mob that killed Yusuf K. Hawkins on a steamy night in Bensonhurst last August. But they said there was not enough evidence to show that the defendant fired the fatal shots. Nine of the jurors who convicted Joseph Fama
title: The Bensonhurst Case; Weary Jury Wasn't Convinced That Fama Was the Gunman

body: LEAD: BROOKLYN has had a long and illustrious history as a center for fine arts and popular amusements. Now, New York's most populous borough is forging a new history, as shown by the array of galleries, nightclubs, performance spaces and food shops that have recently opened. These additions to Brooklyn's cultural map are usually different from
title: A Brooklyn Update: Where the Action Is

body: LEAD: Rather than being concentrated in one area, Brooklyn's food shops are scattered about the borough like raisins in a Lenten hot-cross bun. Here is a sampling of some fairly recent newcomers to Brooklyn's eclectic gastronomic scene. title: New Shops With an Emphasis on the Edible

title: Boerum Hill

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA; Freedom for South African Releases Joy in New York
